doc.abstracts: Belarus has moved very slowly to dismantle its state enterprises and associated trading monopolies. Nevertheless, a private sector clearly is emerging. A recent World Bank survey shows that so far the private sector has developed through three basic channels: 1) start-ups; 2) 100 percent buyouts; and 3) spin-offs. Belarus requires a comprehensive strategy to create a more conducive environment for private sector activities. This Note explains the approach the Bank used for designing such a strategy in Belarus, and it identifies three critical constraints to enterprise development: rudimentary business strategies, ill-defined property rights, and limited availability of investment credit in the high-inflation environment. The private sector survey showed that it is not enough to set up legal infrastructure and institutions. Faster privatization and the tightening of subsidized credits to enterprises need to be implemented together with regulatory reforms and the business centers.
